content.condition: For when the jump feels like there's only one beat instead of two
content.feeling: It feels like there's only one beat to the jump instead of two. There should be two because there is an axis change in the air. If I only feel one, I probably didn't change axis.
content.issue: Not changing axis in the air, causing the jump to feel like one beat instead of two. This happens with symptoms: sassy hip in the load, square hips in the load, turning on the ice before jumping, free leg and arm kicking across body instead of out, stepping down and having to adjust hips/recenter chest/drop (hip isn't engaging), and even with all of this, unless I prime the glute medius to fire, I'm still sassy-ing a little.
content.solution: Address the root causes: Lower body - Set: Squeeze free glute medius and engage skating inner thigh to align free leg's foot, knee, and hip. Step: Step perpendicular to skating edge, not parallel. Load: Switch hips - lift free side instead of loading with flat hips. Upper body - Set: Belly button should track knee and foot, not be behind the path of free side, to enable hinging onto standing hip.
content.regressions: Watch for: sassy hip, square hips, turning on ice before jumping, free leg and arm kicking across body, stepping down with misalignment. Use drills: Set up jumps with marking posts, do baby waltz jump but jump straight, hold the load to feel free side staying back and when it releases.

content.condition: Do this if you have a sassy hip in the load
content.feeling: Hip is sassy (sticking out to the side) during the load phase
content.issue: Free glute medius and skating inner thigh not squeezing in the set, causing free leg's foot, knee, and hip to be unaligned. When stepping down, they are already primed to sassy. Even with other fixes, unless glute medius is primed to fire, still sassy-ing a little.
content.solution: On the set, squeeze free glute medius and engage skating inner thigh together. Prime the glute medius to fire. This aligns the free leg's foot, knee, and hip so they're not primed to sassy when stepping down.

content.condition: Do this if you have square hips in the load
content.feeling: Hips are square (not rotated/switched) during the load
content.issue: Not switching hips, loading with flat hips instead of lifting free side
content.solution: Switch hips - lift the free side. Free and standing hips need to switch. After loading and lifting the free hip, then start hinging into the standing hip.

content.condition: Do this if you're turning on the ice before jumping
content.feeling: Rotation happens on the ice before leaving the ice
content.issue: Pre-rotation - turning on the ice instead of in the air
content.solution: Jump straight up, not turning. Set up jumps with marking posts to ensure straight entry.

content.condition: Do this if free leg and arm are kicking across your body instead of out
content.feeling: Free leg and arm move across the body rather than extending outward
content.issue: Free side not staying back, causing compensatory movement across the body
content.solution: Keep free side back. Free leg and arm should extend out, not across the body.

content.condition: Do this if you step down and have to adjust your hips, recenter your chest, and drop
content.feeling: When stepping down, need to make multiple adjustments - hips, chest, and dropping
content.issue: Hip isn't engaging. Belly button not tracking knee and foot in the set, so by the time you step down, you need to shift chest over.
content.solution: On the set, ensure belly button tracks the knee and foot. Engage the hip properly. Prime glute medius to fire.

content.condition: Do this if you're stepping parallel instead of perpendicular to your skating edge
content.feeling: Step direction feels parallel to the edge rather than perpendicular
content.issue: Stepping parallel causes hips to open up excessively, exacerbating sassy hip
content.solution: Step perpendicular to your skating edge, not parallel

Should change in the air - there should be two beats to the jump, not one. If only feeling one beat, axis didn't change.

content.text: Set up my jumps with marking posts
Set: Emphasis on belly button tracking. Anything to engage the inner thighs (ball on between legs or kneeling thigh squeezes with band).

Hold the load and really get a sense of feeling for the free side staying back. This shouldn't be possible forever and so I also need to get a feel for when it starts to release so I can USE THAT to jump.

Load: The lats switch between being 'engaged/squeezing' and static/holding from the entrance to the load. Right side load: The free lat starts squeezing while the skating lat is holding shape. Cross tension (seatbelt): both are holding shape. Left side load: The free lat is squeezing and the skating lat is holding shape. Free and standing glutes should be squeezing together in the set and through the load. Free and standing hips need to switch at the load. After I load and lift the free hip, THEN start hinging into the standing hip and drawing my arms back.
Do a baby waltz jump, but jump straight
